column1: The Philippines ( (listen); Filipino: Pilipinas [ˌpɪlɪˈpinɐs] or Filipinas [fɪlɪˈpinɐs])
column2: officially the Republic of the Philippines (Filipino: Republika ng Pilipinas)
column3: is an archipelagic country in Southeast Asia. Situated in the western Pacific Ocean
column4: it consists of about 7
column5: 641 islands that are broadly categorized under three main geographical divisions from north to south: Luzon
column6: Visayas
column7: Mindanao. The capital city of the Philippines is Manila and the most populous city is Quezon City
column8: both within the single urban area of Metro Manila. Bounded by the South China Sea on the west
column9: the Philippine Sea on the east and the Celebes Sea on the southwest
column10: the Philippines shares maritime borders with Taiwan to the north
column11: Japan to the northeast
column12: Palau to the east
column14: Malaysia and Brunei to the southwest
column15: Vietnam to the west
column16: and China to the northwest.

column1: The Philippines' position as an island country on the Pacific Ring of Fire and close to the equator makes the country prone to earthquakes and typhoons. The country has a variety of natural resources and a globally significant level of biodiversity. The Philippines has an area of around 300
column3: 000 sq mi) with a population of around 109 million people. As of 2020
column4: it is the 8th-most populated country in Asia and the 13th-most populated country in the world. Multiple ethnicities and cultures are found throughout the islands. Negritos
column5: some of the archipelago's earliest inhabitants
column6: were followed by successive waves of Austronesian peoples.

column2: a Portuguese explorer leading a fleet for Spain
column3: marked the beginning of Spanish colonization. In 1543
column4: Spanish explorer Ruy López de Villalobos named the archipelago Las Islas Filipinas in honor of Philip II of Spain. Beginning in 1565
column5: Spanish settlement of the archipelago was established via expeditions organized from New Spain and the Philippines became part of the Spanish Empire for more than 300 years. During this time
column6: Catholicism became the dominant religion
column7: and Manila became the western hub of trans-Pacific trade. In 1896 the Philippine Revolution began
column8: which then became entwined with the 1898 Spanish–American War. Spain ceded the territory to the United States
column9: while Filipino rebels declared the First Philippine Republic. The ensuing Philippine–American War ended with the United States establishing control over the territory
column10: which they maintained until the Japanese invasion of the islands during World War II. Following liberation
column11: the Philippines became an independent country in 1946. Since then
column12: the unitary sovereign state has often had a tumultuous experience with democracy
column13: which included the overthrow of a dictatorship by the People Power Revolution.

column1: The Philippines is a founding member of the United Nations
column2: World Trade Organization
column3: Association of Southeast Asian Nations
column4: the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum
column5: and the East Asia Summit. The Philippines is considered to be an emerging market and a newly industrialized country
column6: which has an economy transitioning from being based on agriculture to being based more on services and manufacturing.

column1: Spanish explorer Ruy López de Villalobos
column2: during his expedition in 1542

column10: a translation of the Spanish name. The full title of the Republic of the Philippines was included in the 1935 constitution as the name of the future independent state.

column1: There is evidence of early hominins living in what is now the Philippines as early as 709

column6: 000 years ago. The oldest modern human remains found on the islands are from the Tabon Caves of Palawan

column9: 000 years ago. The Tabon Man is presumably a Negrito
column10: who were among the archipelago's earliest inhabitants
column11: descendants of the first human migrations out of Africa via the coastal route along southern Asia to the now sunken landmasses of Sundaland and Sahul.The first Austronesians reached the Philippines at around 2200 BC
column12: settling the Batanes Islands and northern Luzon from Taiwan. From there
column13: they rapidly spread downwards to the rest of the islands of the Philippines and Southeast Asia. This population assimilated with the existing Negritos resulting in the modern Filipino ethnic groups which display various ratios of genetic admixture between Austronesian and Negrito groups. Jade artifacts have been found dated to 2000 BC
column14: with the lingling-o jade items crafted in Luzon made using raw materials originating from Taiwan. By 1000 BC
column15: the inhabitants of the archipelago had developed into four kinds of social groups: hunter-gatherer tribes
column16: warrior societies

column1: The earliest known surviving written record found in the Philippines is the Laguna Copperplate Inscription. Many polities in the Philippines developed substantial commercial contacts and military alliances with other polities in East
column2: Southeast
column3: and South Asia. Trade with China is believed to have begun during the Tang dynasty
column4: but grew more extensive during the Song dynasty. By the 2nd century CE

column6: trading but without direct political or military control. Indian cultural traits
column7: such as linguistic terms and religious practices

column9: likely via the Hindu Majapahit empire. By the 13th century

column11: and became the focal point of societal changes. By the 15th century

column14: and Luzon.Polities founded in the Philippines from the 10th–16th centuries include Maynila
column15: Tondo
column16: Namayan
column23: and Ma-i. The early polities of the Philippine archipelago were typically characterized by a three-tier social structure: a nobility class
column25: and a class of dependent debtor-bondsmen. Among the nobility were leaders called "Datus
column26: responsible for ruling autonomous groups called barangay" or "dulohan". Whenever these barangays banded together
column27: either to form a larger settlement or a geographically looser alliance group

column35: Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan arrived and claimed the islands for Spain
column36: allying himself with a native rajah. The natives were recorded as having a high literacy rate
column37: knowing how to read and write in their traditional scripts
column38: while adhering to their indigenous religions. Conflicts with Lapu-Lapu resulted in Spanish defeat during the Battle of Mactan

column1: Colonization began when Spanish explorer Miguel López de Legazpi arrived from Mexico in 1565. In 1571
column2: the Spanish Manila became the capital of the Spanish East Indies
column3: which also encompassed
column4: under varying time frames
column5: the Marianas
column6: Carolines
column7: Palaos and Guam
column8: as well as parts of Taiwan
column9: Sulawesi
column10: and the Moluccas. The Spanish considered their war with the Muslims in Southeast Asia an extension of the Reconquista. Colonizers invaded different local states through the divide and conquer principle. The 1587 Tondo Conspiracy
column11: which attempted to overthrow the colonizers and install the native noble Agustin de Legazpi as Monarch
column12: failed leading to the downfall of numerous native nobles.Spanish rule brought most parts
column14: of the Philippines into a single unified administration. From 1565 to 1821
column15: the Philippines was governed as part of the Mexico-based Viceroyalty of New Spain
column16: later administered from Madrid following the Mexican War of Independence. Manila galleons were constructed in the Bicol and Cavite. Manila was the western hub of the trans-Pacific trade.

column2: Catholic missionaries converted most of the lowland inhabitants who adhered to indigenous religions into colonial Christianity
column3: often done through brutal means
column4: such as genocide. Colonizers founded schools
column5: a university
column6: hospitals
column7: and churches
column8: by imposing an inhumane system of unpaid labor
column9: called polo
column10: among the natives. Military fortresses were established to defend colonial settlements. Natives were enrolled in catechism schools to convert them further into Christianity
column11: while higher Spanish schools barred any native from enrolling. Free public schooling was made only in 1863
column12: as an aftermath of a law in Spain which affected the colony
column14: but later abolished by decree
column15: although the practice still continued. The population increased partly to some policies imposed by the Spanish.During its rule
column16: Spain quelled various indigenous revolts while defending against external military challenges. Spanish campaigns against the natives often resulted in widespread abuse. Spanish influence among the Filipino upper class eventually created a system that became firmly rooted on oligarchy. War against the Dutch in the 17th century
column18: and Japanese-Chinese Wokou piracy nearly bankrupted the colonial treasury. The rice terraces of Ifugao were built by indigenous peoples
column19: in response to colonial encroachment. Desertion rate was high among the Latino soldiers from Mexico and Peru
column23: dislocation and near starvation. Immigration blurred the Spanish racial caste system maintained in towns and cities. The Royal Fiscal of Manila wrote to King Charles III of Spain to abandon the colony amidst difficulty in governing. The advice was opposed by Christian orders who valued the islands for religious conversion of neighboring Asian nations.

column1: The Philippines survived on an annual subsidy provided by the Spanish Crown sent from the Americas. Century-old fortifications did not see significant upgrades
column2: allowing British forces to occupy Manila from 1762 to 1764 during the Seven Years' War against Spain
column3: killing and wounding hundreds of Filipinos. British expansion was prevented by Filipino resistance
column4: until Spanish rule was restored through the 1763 Treaty of Paris.In the 19th century
column5: Spanish Philippine ports further opened to world trade. Many Spaniards born in the Philippines and those of mixed ancestry were wealthy
column6: and an influx of Hispanic American immigrants opened up government positions traditionally held by Spaniards born in the Iberian Peninsula
column7: while ideas of rebellion and independence began to spread. Many Latin-Americans and Criollos staffed the Spanish Philippine army
column8: but their loyalty was doubted due to the Latin American wars of independence made worse by a Mexican of Filipino descent
column9: Isidoro Montes de Oca
column10: being captain-general in the Mexican War of Independence. To prevent a rebel union of Latinos and Filipinos
column11: the Latino and Criollo officers stationed in the Philippines were replaced by Peninsular Spanish officers
column12: who were less committed to the people and were often predatory
column13: enriching themselves before returning to Spain. The Spanish–Moro conflict lasted for several hundred years until a peace treaty was signed on April 30

column20: the insurgent Tagalog Republic and the Republic of Zamboanga. Throughout these campaigns

column1: Situated on the western fringes of the Pacific Ring of Fire
column2: the Philippines experiences frequent seismic and volcanic activity. The Benham Plateau to the east in the Philippine Sea is an undersea region active in tectonic subduction. Around 20 earthquakes are registered daily
column3: though most are too weak to be felt. The last major earthquake was the 1990 Luzon earthquake. There are many active volcanoes such as the Mayon Volcano
column4: Mount Pinatubo
column5: and Taal Volcano. The eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June 1991 produced the second largest terrestrial eruption of the 20th century. The Philippines is the world's second-biggest geothermal energy producer behind the United States
column6: with 18% of the country's electricity needs being met by geothermal power.Significant mineral deposits exist as a result of the country's complex geologic structure and high level of seismic activity. These deposites are considered highly valuable. The country is thought to have the second-largest gold deposits after South Africa
column7: along with a large amount of copper deposits. Palladium
column8: originally discovered in South America
column9: was found to have the world's largest deposits in the Philippines too. Romblon island is a source of high-quality marble. Other minerals include chromite
column10: nickel
column11: and zinc. Despite this
column12: a lack of law enforcement
column14: opposition due to the presence of indigenous communities
column15: and past instances of environmental damages and disasters
column16: have resulted in these mineral resources remaining largely untapped.

column1: The Philippines is a megadiverse country. Around 1
column2: 100 land vertebrate species can be found in the Philippines including over 100 mammal species and 170 bird species not thought to exist elsewhere. The Philippines has among the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of mammals discovered in the last ten years. Because of this
column3: the rate of endemism for the Philippines has risen and likely will continue to rise. Parts of its marine waters contain the highest diversity of shorefish species in the world.Large reptiles include the Philippine crocodile and saltwater crocodile. The largest crocodile in captivity
column4: known locally as Lolong

column6: and died on 10 February 2013 from pneumonia and cardiac arrest. The national bird
column7: known as the Philippine eagle

column1: The Philippines has a tropical maritime climate that is usually hot and humid. There are three seasons: tag-init or tag-araw
column2: the hot dry season or summer from March to May; tag-ulan
column3: the rainy season from June to November; and tag-lamig
column4: the cool dry season from December to February. The southwest monsoon (from May to October) is known as the Habagat
column5: and the dry winds of the northeast monsoon (from November to April)
column6: the Amihan. Temperatures usually range from 21 °C (70 °F) to 32 °C (90 °F) although it can get cooler or hotter depending on the season. The coolest month is January; the warmest is May.The average yearly temperature is around 26.6 °C (79.9 °F). In considering temperature
column7: location in terms of latitude and longitude is not a significant factor. Whether in the extreme north
column8: south
column9: east
column10: or west of the country
column11: temperatures at sea level tend to be in the same range. Altitude usually has more of an impact. The average annual temperature of Baguio at an elevation of 1
column12: 500 meters (4
column14: making it a popular destination during hot summers. Annual rainfall measures as much as 5
column15: 000 millimeters (200 in) in the mountainous east coast section but less than 1
column16: 000 millimeters (39 in) in some of the sheltered valleys.Sitting astride the typhoon belt
column17: the islands experience 15-20 typhoons annually from July to October
column18: with around nineteen typhoons entering the Philippine area of responsibility in a typical year and eight or nine making landfall. Historically typhoons were sometimes referred to as baguios. The wettest recorded typhoon to hit the Philippines dropped 2
column19: 210 millimeters (87 in) in Baguio from 14–18 July 1911. The Philippines is highly exposed to climate change and is among the world's ten countries that are most vulnerable to climate change risks.

column1: The Commission on Population estimated the country's population to be 107

The 2.34% average annual population growth rate between 1990 and 2000 decreased to an estimated 1.90% for the 2000–2010 period. Government attempts to reduce population growth have been a contentious issue. The population's median age is 22.7 years with 60.9% aged from 15 to 64 years old. Life expectancy at birth is 69.4 years

Poverty incidence dropped to 21.6% in 2015 from 25.2% in 2012.Metro Manila is the most populous of the 3 defined metropolitan areas in the Philippines and the 5th most populous in the world. Census data from 2015 showed it had a population of 12

Metro Manila's gross regional product was estimated as of 2009 to be ₱468.4 billion (at constant 1985 prices) and accounts for 33% of the nation's GDP. In 2011 Manila ranked as the 28th wealthiest urban agglomeration in the world and the 2nd in Southeast Asia.

There is some uncertainty over the origin of this Austronesian speaking population

column1: The Philippines is a secular state which protects freedom of religion. Christianity is the dominant faith
column2: shared by over 90% of the population. Census data from 2015 found that about 79.53% of the population professed Catholicism. Around 37% of the population regularly attend Mass. 29% of self-identified Catholics consider themselves very religious. An independent Catholic church
column3: the Philippine Independent Church
column4: has around 66
column5: 959 adherents.Protestants were 10.8% of the population in 2010. 2.64% of the population are members of Iglesia ni Cristo. The combined following of the Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches comes to 2.42% of the total population.Islam is the second largest religion. The Muslim population of the Philippines was reported as 6.01% of the total population according to census returns in 2015. Conversely
column6: a 2012 report by the National Commission of Muslim Filipinos (NCMF) stated that about 10
column8: 000 or 11% of Filipinos are Muslims. The majority of Muslims live in Mindanao and nearby islands. Most practice Sunni Islam under the Shafi'i school.The percentage of combined positive atheist and agnostic people in the Philippines was measured to be about 3% of the population as of 2008. The 2015 Philippine Census reported the religion of about 0.02% of the population as "none". A 2014 survey by Gallup International Association reported that 21% of its respondents identify as "not a religious person".Around 0.24% of the population practice indigenous Philippine folk religions
column9: whose practices and folk beliefs are often syncretized with Christianity and Islam. Buddhism is practiced by around 0.03% of the population
column10: concentrated among Filipinos of Chinese descent.

column1: The Philippines had a simple literacy rate of 98.3% as of 2015

column1: The Philippines has a democratic government in the form of a constitutional republic with a presidential system. It is governed as a unitary state
column2: with the exception of the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM)
column3: although there has been several steps towards decentralization within the unitary framework. There have been attempts to change the government to a federal
column4: unicameral
column5: or parliamentary government since the Ramos administration. There is a significant amount of corruption in the Philippines
column6: which some historians attribute to the system of governance put in place during the Spanish colonial period.The President functions as both head of state and head of government and is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by popular vote for a single six-year term
column7: during which he or she appoints and presides over the cabinet. The current President is Rodrigo Duterte. The bicameral Congress is composed of the Senate
column8: serving as the upper house
column9: with members elected to a six-year term
column10: and the House of Representatives
column11: serving as the lower house
column12: with members elected to a three-year term. Philippine politics tends to be dominated by those with well-known names
column13: such as members of political dynasties or celebrities.Senators are elected at large while the representatives are elected from both legislative districts and through sectoral representation. The judicial power is vested in the Supreme Court
column14: composed of a Chief Justice as its presiding officer and fourteen associate justices
column15: all of whom are appointed by the President from nominations submitted by the Judicial and Bar Council. The capital city of the Philippines is Manila and the most populous city is Quezon City
column16: both within the single urban area of Metro Manila.

column1: As a founding and active member of the United Nations
column2: the country has been elected to the Security Council. Carlos P. Romulo was a former President of the United Nations General Assembly. The country is an active participant in the Human Rights Council as well as in peacekeeping missions
column3: particularly in East Timor. Over 10 million Filipinos live and work overseas.The Philippines is a founding and active member of ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations). It has hosted several summits and is an active contributor to the direction and policies of the bloc. It is also a member of the East Asia Summit (EAS)
column4: the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)
column5: the Group of 24
column6: and the Non-Aligned Movement. The country is also seeking to obtain observer status in the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation.The Philippines has a long relationship with the United States
column7: covering economics
column8: security
column9: and people-to-people relations. A mutual defense treaty between the two countries was signed in 1951
column10: and supplemented later with the 1999 Visiting Forces Agreement and the 2016 Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement. The Philippines supported American policies during the Cold War and participated in the Korean and Vietnam wars. In 2003 the Philippines was designated a Major non-NATO ally. Controversies related to the presence of the now former U.S. military bases in Subic Bay and Clark and the current Visiting Forces Agreement have flared up from time to time.

column1: Under President Duterte ties with the United States have weakened with military purchases instead coming from China and Russia
column2: while Duterte states that the Philippines will no longer participate in any US-led wars.The Philippines attaches great importance in its relations with China
column3: and has established significant cooperation with the country. Japan is the biggest bilateral contributor of official development assistance to the country. Although historical tensions exist due to the events of World War II
column4: much of the animosity has faded.Historical and cultural ties continue to affect relations with Spain. Relations with Middle Eastern countries are shaped by the high number of Filipinos working in these countries
column5: and by issues relating the Muslim minority in the Philippines. Concerns have been raised regarding issues such as domestic abuse and war affecting the around 2.5 million overseas Filipino workers in the region.The Philippines has claims in the Spratly Islands which overlap with claims by China
column6: Malaysia
column7: Taiwan
column8: and Vietnam. The largest of its controlled islands in Thitu Island
column9: which contains the Philippine's smallest village. The Scarborough Shoal standoff in 2012
column10: where China took control of the shoal from the Philippines
column11: led to an international arbitration case and has made the shoal a prominent symbol in the wider dispute.

column1: The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) consist of three branches: the Philippine Air Force
column2: the Philippine Army
column3: and the Philippine Navy. The Armed Forces of the Philippines are a volunteer force. Civilian security is handled by the Philippine National Police under the Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG).In the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
column4: the largest separatist organization
column5: the Moro National Liberation Front is now engaging the government politically. Other more militant groups like the Moro Islamic Liberation Front
column6: and the Abu Sayyaf have kidnapped foreigners for ransom
column7: particularly in Mindanao. Their presence decreased due to successful security provided by the Philippine government. The Communist Party of the Philippines and its military wing
column8: the New People's Army
column9: have been waging guerrilla warfare against the government since the 1970s
column10: reaching its apex in 1986 when Communist guerrillas gained control of a fifth of the country's territory
column11: before significantly dwindling militarily and politically after the return of democracy in 1986. As of 2018
column12: $2.843 billion
column13: or 1.1 percent of GDP is spent on military forces.

column1: The Philippines is divided into three island groups: Luzon
column2: the Visayas
column3: and Mindanao. These are further divided into 17 regions
column4: 81 provinces
column5: 146 cities
column7: 488 municipalities
column8: and 42

column10: Calabarzon was the most populated region while the National Capital Region (NCR) the most densely populated.

column1: The Philippine economy has produced an estimated gross domestic product (nominal) of $356.8 billion. Primary exports include semiconductors and electronic products
column2: transport equipment
column3: garments
column4: copper products
column5: petroleum products
column6: coconut oil
column7: and fruits. Major trading partners include the United States
column8: Japan
column9: China
column10: Singapore
column11: South Korea
column12: the Netherlands
column14: Germany
column15: Taiwan
column16: and Thailand. Its unit of currency is the Philippine peso (₱ or PHP).A newly industrialized country
column17: the Philippine economy has been transitioning from one based upon agriculture to an economy with more emphasis upon services and manufacturing. Of the country's 2018 labor force of around 43.46 million
column19: and accounted for 8.1% of 2018 GDP. The industrial sector employed around 19% of the workforce and accounted for 34.1% of GDP
column20: while 57% of the workers involved in the services sector were responsible for 57.8% of GDP.The unemployment rate as of October 2019
column22: due to lower charges in basic necessities
column23: the inflation rate eased to 1.7% in August 2019. Gross international reserves as of October 2013 are $83.201 billion. The Debt-to-GDP ratio continues to decline to 37.6% as of the second quarter of 2019 from a record high of 78% in 2004. The country is a net importer but it is also a creditor nation. Manila hosts the headquarters of the Asian Development Bank.

column1: The 1997 Asian Financial Crisis affected the economy
column2: resulting in a lingering decline of the value of the peso and falls in the stock market. The extent it was affected initially was not as severe as that of some of its Asian neighbors. This was largely due to the fiscal conservatism of the government
column3: partly as a result of decades of monitoring and fiscal supervision from the International Monetary Fund (IMF)
column4: in comparison to the massive spending of its neighbors on the rapid acceleration of economic growth. There have been signs of progress since. In 2004
column5: the economy experienced 6.4% GDP growth and 7.1% in 2007
column6: its fastest pace of growth in three decades. Average annual GDP growth per capita for the period 1966–2007 still stands at 1.45% in comparison to an average of 5.96% for the East Asia and the Pacific region as a whole. The daily income for 45% of the population of the Philippines remains less than $2.Remittances from overseas Filipinos contribute significantly to the Philippine economy
column7: surpassing foreign direct investment as a source of foreign currency. Remittances peaked in 2006 at 10.4% of the national GDP
column8: and were 8.6% and 8.5% in 2012 and in 2014 respectively. In 2014 the total worth of foreign exchange remittances was US$28 billion. Regional development is uneven
column9: with Luzon – Metro Manila in particular – gaining most of the new economic growth at the expense of the other regions
column10: although the government has taken steps to distribute economic growth by promoting investment in other areas of the country. Service industries such as Tourism in the Philippines and business process outsourcing have been identified as areas with some of the best opportunities for growth for the country. The Business Process Outsourcing (BPO) industry is composed of eight sub-sectors
column11: namely
column12: knowledge process outsourcing and back offices
column14: call centers
column15: software development
column16: game development
column19: the Philippines was reported as having eclipsed India as the main center of BPO services in the world.

column1: The Department of Science and Technology is the governing agency responsible for the development of coordination of science and technology-related projects in the Philippines. Research organizations in the country include the International Rice Research Institute
column2: which focuses on the development of new rice varieties and rice crop management techniques.The Philippines bought its first satellite in 1996. In 2016

column6: the nation sent an average of one billion SMS messages per day. The country has a high level of mobile financial services utilization. The Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company
column7: commonly known as PLDT

column9: adjudication and control over all telecommunications services throughout the country. There are approximately 417 AM and 1079 FM radio stations and 438 television and 1
column10: 551 cable television stations. On March 29
column12: the country was connected to the Internet via a 64 kbit/s connection from a router serviced by PLDT to a Sprint router in California. Estimates for Internet penetration in the Philippines vary widely ranging from a low of 2.5 million to a high of 24 million people. Social networking and watching videos are among the most frequent Internet activities. The Philippine population is the world's top internet user.

column1: Transportation in the Philippines is facilitated by road
column2: air
column3: rail and waterways. As of December 2018

column5: 528 kilometers (130
column6: 816 mi) of roads in the Philippines
column7: with only 65

column11: Samar

column15: carrying 98% of people and 58% of cargo. A network of expressways extends from the capital to other areas of Luzon. The 8.25-kilometre (5.13 mi) Cebu–Cordova Link Expressway in Cebu will be finished by 2021. Traffic is a significant issue facing the country
column16: especially within Manila and on arterial roads connecting to the capital.Public transport in the country include buses
column22: and tricycles. Jeepneys are a popular and iconic public utility vehicle. Jeepneys and other Public Utility Vehicles which are older than 15 years are being phased out gradually in favor of a more efficient and environmentally friendly Euro 4 compliant vehicles.Despite wider historical use
column23: Rail transport in the Philippines is extremely limited
column24: being confined to transporting passengers within Metro Manila and neighboring Laguna

column27: which it had plans to expand up to 244 kilometers. Metro Manila is served by three rapid transit lines: Line 1

column31: and the 109-kilometre (68 mi) PNR North-South Commuter Railway which is divided into several phases
column32: with partial operations to begin in 2022. The civil airline industry is regulated by the Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines. Philippine Airlines is Asia's oldest commercial airline still operating under its original name. Cebu Pacific is the countries leading low-cost carrier.As an archipelago
column33: inter-island travel using watercraft is often necessary. Boats have always been important to societies in the Philippines. Most boats are double-outrigger vessels
column34: which can reach up to 30 metres (98 ft) in length
column38: or balanghay. A variety of boat types are used throughout the islands
column39: such as dugouts (baloto) and house-boats like the lepa-lepa. Terms such as bangka and baroto are also used as general names for a variety of boat types. Modern ships use plywood in place of logs and motor engines in place of sails. These ships are used both for fishing and for inter-island travel. The principal seaports of Manila
column47: and Zamboanga form part of the ASEAN Transport Network. The Pasig River Ferry serves the cities of Manila
column50: Pasig and Marikina in Metro Manila.

column2: affordable

column1: Filipino culture is a combination of Eastern and Western cultures. The Philippines exhibits aspects found in other Asian countries with a Malay heritage
column2: yet its culture also displays a significant number of Spanish and American influences. Traditional festivities known as barrio fiestas (district festivals) to commemorate the feast days of patron saints are common
column3: these community celebrations are times for feasting
column4: music
column5: and dancing. The Ati-Atihan
column6: Moriones and Sinulog festivals are among the most well-known. The culture within Mindanao and the Sulu Archipelago developed separately to that of the rest of the country
column7: due to very limited degree of Spanish influence and greater influence from nearby Islamic regions.Some traditions
column8: however
column9: are changing or gradually being forgotten due to modernization. The Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company has been lauded for preserving many of the various traditional folk dances found throughout the Philippines. They are famed for their iconic performances of Philippine dances such as the tinikling and singkil that both feature clashing bamboo poles.One of the most visible Hispanic legacies is the prevalence of Spanish names and surnames among Filipinos; a Spanish name and surname
column10: however
column11: does not necessarily denote Spanish ancestry. This peculiarity
column12: unique among the people of Asia
column13: came as a result of a colonial edict by Governor-General Narciso Clavería y Zaldua
column14: which ordered the systematic distribution of family names and implementation of Hispanic nomenclature on the population. The names of many locations are also Spanish
column15: or stem from Spanish roots and origins.The common use of the English language is an example of the American impact on Philippine society. It has contributed to the ready acceptance and influence of American pop cultural trends. This affinity is seen in Filipinos' love of fast food and American film and music. Fast food outlets are found on many street corners. American global fast-food chain stalwarts have entered the market
column16: but local fast-food chains like Goldilocks and most notably Jollibee
column17: the leading fast-food chain in the country
column18: have emerged and compete successfully against foreign chains.

column8: and heroes
column9: such as Bathala

column23: and sarimanok.Philippine literature comprises works usually written in Filipino
column25: or English. Some of the most known were created from the 17th to 19th century. Adarna
column27: is a famous epic about an eponymous magical bird allegedly written by José de la Cruz or "Huseng Sisiw". Francisco Balagtas
column28: the poet and playwright who wrote Florante at Laura
column29: is recognized as a preeminent writer in the Tagalog (Filipino) language. José Rizal wrote the novels Noli Me Tángere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (The Filibustering
column30: also known as The Reign of Greed).

column1: Spanish architecture has left an imprint in the Philippines in the way many towns were designed around a central square or plaza mayor
column2: but many of the buildings bearing its influence were demolished during World War II. Four Philippine baroque churches are included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites: the San Agustín Church in Manila
column3: Paoay Church in Ilocos Norte
column4: Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Santa María) Church in Ilocos Sur
column5: and Santo Tomás de Villanueva Church in Iloilo. Vigan in Ilocos Sur is also known for the many Hispanic-style houses and buildings preserved there.American rule introduced new architectural styles. This led to the construction of government buildings and Art Deco theaters. During the American period
column6: some semblance of city planning using the architectural designs and master plans by Daniel Burnham was done on the portions of the city of Manila. Part of the Burnham plan was the construction of government buildings that resembled Greek or Neoclassical architecture. In Iloilo
column7: structures from both the Spanish and American periods can still be seen
column8: especially in Calle Real. Certain areas of the country like Batanes have slight differences as both Spanish and Filipino ways of architecture assimilated differently due to the climate. Limestones were used as a building material
column9: with houses being built to withstand typhoons.

column1: Pre-colonial tribal music includes Koyu No Tebulul of the T'boli and Ambo Hato of the Ifugao. This genre is often accompanied by gong music and one well known instrument is the Kulintang. During the Spanish era Rondalya music
column2: where traditional string orchestra mandolin type instruments were used
column3: was widespread. Nowadays
column4: American pop culture has a heavy hold on the Filipinos that evolved from the Spanish times when the American occupation happened. Recently K-pop has become popular. Karaoke is a popular event in the country. The revival of Spanish-influence folk music has been possible thanks to the different choir groups coming in and going out of the country
column5: such as the Philippine Madrigal Singers.

column1: The Philippines has a wide array of ethnic dances from different tribal groups. Spanish-influenced dances are found in both Luzon and Visayas
column2: whereas Mindanao dances are often more Muslim inspired with Spanish influence limited to the region of Zamboanga.One famous dance that is well known is called the Tinikling
column3: where a band of Rondalya musicians play along with the percussive beat of the two bamboo poles. It usually starts with men and women acting a scene about "How rural townsfolk mingle". The dancers then graze thru the clashing of the bamboo poles held on opposite sides. The end displays the paired bamboo poles crossing each other. The Muslim version of this where bamboo poles are also used is called the Singkil. Cariñosa is a Hispanic Filipino dance
column4: unofficially considered as the "National Dance of the Philippines". It is a courtship dance which involves a woman holding a fan or a handkerchief
column5: where it plays an instrumental role as it places the couple in romance scenario.In the Modern and Post-Modern time periods
column6: dances may vary from the delicate ballet up to the more street-oriented styles of breakdancing.

column2: the distinct value system of Filipinos is rooted primarily in personal alliance systems
column3: especially those based in kinship
column4: obligation
column5: friendship
column6: religion (particularly Christianity)
column7: and commercial relationships.Filipino values are
column8: for the most part
column9: centered around maintaining social harmony
column10: motivated primarily by the desire to be accepted within a group. The main sanction against diverging from these values are the concepts of "Hiya"
column11: roughly translated as 'a sense of shame'
column12: and "Amor propio" or 'self-esteem'. Social approval
column14: and belonging to a group are major concerns. Caring about what others will think
column15: say or do
column16: are strong influences on social behavior among Filipinos.Other elements of the Filipino value system are optimism about the future
column17: pessimism about present situations and events
column18: concern and care for other people
column19: the existence of friendship and friendliness
column23: respect for the female members of society
column25: and abhorrence of acts of cheating and thievery.

column1: Filipino cuisine has evolved over several centuries from its Malayo-Polynesian origins to become a mixed cuisine with Chinese
column2: American
column3: and other Asian influences. The most dominant influence however is Spanish
column4: which has influenced up to 80% of Filipino recipes. Regional variations exist throughout the islands
column5: for example rice is a standard starch in Luzon while cassava is more common in Mindanao. Dishes range from the very simple
column6: like a meal of fried salted fish and rice
column7: to the elaborate
column8: such as the paellas and cocidos created for fiestas. Popular dishes include lechón
column9: adobo
column10: sinigang
column11: kare-kare
column12: tapa
column14: pancit
column15: lumpia
column16: and halo-halo. Some common local ingredients used in cooking are calamansi
column18: saba (a kind of short wide plantain)
column22: and fish sauce. Filipino taste buds tend to favor robust flavors
column23: but the cuisine is not as spicy as those of its neighbors.Unlike many Asians
column24: most Filipinos do not eat with chopsticks; they use Western cutlery. However
column25: possibly due to rice being the primary staple food and the popularity of a large number of stews and main dishes with broth in Filipino cuisine
column26: the main pairing of utensils seen at the Filipino dining table is that of spoon and fork
column27: not knife and fork.The traditional way of eating with the hands known as kamayan (using the hand for bringing food to the mouth) was previously more often seen in the less urbanized areas. However
column28: due to the various Filipino restaurants that introduced Filipino food to people of other nationalities
column29: as well as to Filipino urbanites
column30: kamayan fast became popular. This recent trend also sometimes incorporates the "Boodle fight" concept (as popularized and coined by the Philippine Army)
column31: wherein banana leaves are used as giant plates on top of which rice portions and Filipino viands are placed all together for a filial

column1: Philippine media uses mainly Filipino and English

There are large numbers of both radio stations and newspapers.  The top three newspapers by nationwide readership as well as credibility are the Philippine Daily Inquirer

column12: Duterte accused ABS-CBN of being biased against his administration and vowed to block the renewal of their franchise. However
column14: human rights groups
column15: and media unions said the shutdown of ABS-CBN was an attack on press freedom. On July 10
column17: the House of Representatives declined a renewal of ABS-CBN's TV and radio franchise
column22: remain the top source of news and information for majority of Filipinos as newspaper readership continues to decline. English broadsheets are popular among executives
column23: professionals and students. Cheaper Tagalog tabloids
column28: and tend to be popular among the masses

column1: Philippine cinema has a long history and is popular domestically
column2: but has faced increasing competition from American
column3: Asian and European films. Critically acclaimed directors and actors include Lino Brocka and Nora Aunor for films like Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light) and Himala (Miracle). Moving pictures were first shown in the Philippines on January 1
column4: 1897. All films were all in Spanish since Philippine cinema was first introduced during the final years of the Spanish era of the country. Antonio Ramos was the first known movie producer. Meanwhile
column5: Jose Nepomuceno was dubbed as the "Father of Philippine Movies". His work marked the start of the local production of movies. Production companies remained small during the era of silent film
column6: but 1933 saw the emergence of sound films and the arrival of the first significant production company. The postwar 1940s and the 1950s are regarded as a high point for Philippine cinema.During the 1960s
column7: James Bond movies
column8: bomba (soft porn) pictures and an era of musical films
column9: produced mostly by Sampaguita Pictures
column10: dominated the cinema. The second golden age occurred from the 1970s to early 1980s. It was during this era that filmmakers ceased to produce pictures in black and white. The growing dominance of Hollywood films and the cost of production has severely reduced local filmmaking. Nonetheless
column11: some local films continue to find success.

column1: Various sports and pastimes are popular in the Philippines including basketball
column2: boxing
column3: volleyball
column4: football (soccer)
column5: American football
column6: both codes of Rugby football
column7: badminton
column8: karate
column9: taekwondo
column10: billiards
column11: ten-pin bowling
column12: chess
column14: cycling
column15: and mountaineering are also becoming popular. Basketball is played at both amateur and professional levels and is considered to be the most popular sport in the Philippines. In 2010
column16: Manny Pacquiao was named "Fighter of the Decade" for the 2000s by the Boxing Writers Association of America. The national martial art and sport of the country is Arnis.Beginning in 1924
column17: the Philippines has competed in every Summer Olympic Games
column18: except when they participated in the American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics. The Philippines is also the first tropical nation to compete at the Winter Olympic Games debuting in the 1972 edition.

column1: Traditional Philippine games such as luksung baka
column2: patintero
column3: piko
column4: and tumbang preso are played primarily as children's games among the youth. Sabong or cockfighting is another popular entertainment especially among Filipino men
column5: and was documented by Magellan's voyage as a pastime in the kingdom of Taytay. The yo-yo
column6: a popular toy in the Philippines
column7: was introduced in its modern form by Pedro Flores with its name coming from the Ilocano language.
